pullrequest.title: [A-3] Dockerfile and supporting scripts for building ign-gazebo

content.raw:
If this is a valid thing to include here in this repository, I will also update the readme \(or create a separate one for docker\)

To build with the subdirectory:

`docker build . -f ./docker/Dockerfile.base -t ign-gazebo:base`  
`docker build . -f ./docker/Dockerfile.nightly -t ign-gazebo:nightly`

Then run with:

`docker run -it ign-gazebo:nightly /bin/bash`
content.html:
If this is a valid thing to include here in this repository, I will also update the readme (or create a separate one for docker)

To build with the subdirectory:

docker build . -f ./docker/Dockerfile.base -t ign-gazebo:base
docker build . -f ./docker/Dockerfile.nightly -t ign-gazebo:nightly

Then run with:

docker run -it ign-gazebo:nightly /bin/bash

content.raw: Interestingly, I think that everything up to here could be cached as the ign-gazebo:base image, and we wouldn’t have to do it with each CI.

pullrequest.title: [A-3] Dockerfile and supporting scripts for building ign-gazebo

content.raw:
Some thoughts about these changes:

* I'm not a big fan of hosting infra stuff in the software repositories. I know is pretty convenient for the people using them but is a hell to maintain. It's true that the use of pipelines is already doing it, I would like to reduce the code hosted in pipelines instead of adding more. A possible solution would be to move chunks of code to release-tools \(or any other centralized place\) and use the code from there, depending on the flexibility of the pipelines. I'm speaking for example of coding `common_deps` \(or other dependencies\) inside this repo instead of a centralized place.
*  The way of easily using a docker container for development or distributing code has been explored lately at least in two places: the gazebo developers tool  [[https://github.com/osrf/gzdev/](https://github.com/osrf/gzdev/)](https://github.com/osrf/gzdev) \(work in progress, not yet ready\) or rocker [https://github.com/osrf/rocker](https://github.com/osrf/rocker) . I think that both approaches \(pretty similar both, probably should be merged\) are a good way to provide convenient working/testing/CI environments for users.
* Caching dependencies to speed up things in CI is something we are doing, limited to per-computer cache \(not sharing docker images across machines using a docker hub account\). From my experience I would say that although it offers big gains in time you need to be careful and have a plan to get updates \(ubuntu releases new versions rarely but we release new versions of ignition libraries very often\). There is [some code in release-tools](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/release-tools/src/4b34dd59e8785acac4578a1d222af98521ef0114/jenkins-scripts/docker/lib/docker_generate_dockerfile.bash#lines-242) \(lines 242..261\) specifically dealing with the problem of caching.
content.html:
Some thoughts about these changes:

  • I'm not a big fan of hosting infra stuff in the software repositories. I know is pretty convenient for the people using them but is a hell to maintain. It's true that the use of pipelines is already doing it, I would like to reduce the code hosted in pipelines instead of adding more. A possible solution would be to move chunks of code to release-tools (or any other centralized place) and use the code from there, depending on the flexibility of the pipelines. I'm speaking for example of coding common_deps (or other dependencies) inside this repo instead of a centralized place.
  • The way of easily using a docker container for development or distributing code has been explored lately at least in two places: the gazebo developers tool [https://github.com/osrf/gzdev/](https://github.com/osrf/gzdev/) (work in progress, not yet ready) or rocker https://github.com/osrf/rocker . I think that both approaches (pretty similar both, probably should be merged) are a good way to provide convenient working/testing/CI environments for users.
  • Caching dependencies to speed up things in CI is something we are doing, limited to per-computer cache (not sharing docker images across machines using a docker hub account). From my experience I would say that although it offers big gains in time you need to be careful and have a plan to get updates (ubuntu releases new versions rarely but we release new versions of ignition libraries very often). There is some code in release-tools (lines 242..261) specifically dealing with the problem of caching.

pullrequest.title: [A-3] Dockerfile and supporting scripts for building ign-gazebo

content.raw:
In this case I’m trying to specifically create containers for distributed simulation, the caching for pipelines was something I observed while I was putting this together.  

I’m definitely in favor of moving things to a centralized place where ever possible.   Maybe it’s just a matter of making the pipelines use what we’ve already created for Jenkins?  Additionally, I would be open to utilizing existing containers/infra wherever possible here.

In this case, I would say that the base image specifically excludes any of our stuff \(and has primarily upstream ubuntu dependencies\).  I like the idea of occasionally invalidating the cache in that base layer though, to make sure everything stays up to date.
content.html:
In this case I’m trying to specifically create containers for distributed simulation, the caching for pipelines was something I observed while I was putting this together.

I’m definitely in favor of moving things to a centralized place where ever possible. Maybe it’s just a matter of making the pipelines use what we’ve already created for Jenkins? Additionally, I would be open to utilizing existing containers/infra wherever possible here.

In this case, I would say that the base image specifically excludes any of our stuff (and has primarily upstream ubuntu dependencies). I like the idea of occasionally invalidating the cache in that base layer though, to make sure everything stays up to date.

pullrequest.title: [A-3] Dockerfile and supporting scripts for building ign-gazebo

content.raw:
I think this file can be substituted with  [dependencies_archive.sh](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/release-tools/src/4f00a7f3e27e141bdff7b1864a91e39dac290132/jenkins-scripts/lib/dependencies_archive.sh?fileviewer=file-view-default#dependencies_archive.sh-717) , it will just need to set the correct variables, something like this?

~~~
wget https://bitbucket.org/osrf/release-tools/raw/default/jenkins-scripts/lib/dependencies_archive.sh -O /tmp/dependencies.sh
# I think it may need to set more vars here
GAZEBO_MAJOR_VERSION=dummy ROS_DISTRO=dummy . /tmp/dependencies.sh
echo $IGN_GAZEBO_DEPENDENCIES | tr -d '\\' | xargs sudo apt-get -y install
~~~
content.html:
I think this file can be substituted with dependencies_archive.sh , it will just need to set the correct variables, something like this?

wget https://bitbucket.org/osrf/release-tools/raw/default/jenkins-scripts/lib/dependencies_archive.sh -O /tmp/dependencies.sh
# I think it may need to set more vars here
GAZEBO_MAJOR_VERSION=dummy ROS_DISTRO=dummy . /tmp/dependencies.sh
echo $IGN_GAZEBO_DEPENDENCIES | tr -d '\\' | xargs sudo apt-get -y install

pullrequest.title: [A-3] Dockerfile and supporting scripts for building ign-gazebo

content.raw: We could remove dependencies that are pulled by other debian packages from here. For example, DART should pull boost by itself, ign-math should pull eigen... This means less places to keep track of dependencies.
content.html: We could remove dependencies that are pulled by other debian packages from here. For example, DART should pull boost by itself, ign-math should pull eigen... This means less places to keep track of dependencies.

pullrequest.title: [A-3] Dockerfile and supporting scripts for building ign-gazebo

content.raw: This is populating a “base” layer that’s expected to change a little more slowly than the top of the stack.  I may be mixing docker-for-development and docker-for-deployment practices a bit too much here.  What you suggest would be the best for deployment.
content.html: This is populating a “base” layer that’s expected to change a little more slowly than the top of the stack. I may be mixing docker-for-development and docker-for-deployment practices a bit too much here. What you suggest would be the best for deployment.

pullrequest.title: [A-3] Dockerfile and supporting scripts for building ign-gazebo

content.raw:
If this is meant for deployment, I would suggest removing all the dev dependencies like doxygen, and let all ign library dependencies be pulled by the debs. The idea is to remove duplication. If DART removes the boost dependency in the future, there's no risk we will keep installing boost with no need. Makes sense?

I think it's also useful to have docker-for-development though, in which case the ignition libraries would all be built from source and in that case we do need to pull their dependencies one by one. But even in that case, I imagine we would install DART from debs.
content.html:
If this is meant for deployment, I would suggest removing all the dev dependencies like doxygen, and let all ign library dependencies be pulled by the debs. The idea is to remove duplication. If DART removes the boost dependency in the future, there's no risk we will keep installing boost with no need. Makes sense?

I think it's also useful to have docker-for-development though, in which case the ignition libraries would all be built from source and in that case we do need to pull their dependencies one by one. But even in that case, I imagine we would install DART from debs.

pullrequest.title: [A-3] Dockerfile and supporting scripts for building ign-gazebo

content.raw:
Did I pass the test?

I hacked together my own build script, and ran into the following problems within the docker container.

1. I had to `export LD_LIBRARY_PATH=/usr/local/lib:$LD_LIBRARY_PATH`
2. running `ign-gazebo` results in the following error:

```
QStandardPaths: XDG_RUNTIME_DIR not set, defaulting to '/tmp/runtime-root'
qt.qpa.screen: QXcbConnection: Could not connect to display 
Could not connect to any X display.
```
content.html:
Did I pass the test?

I hacked together my own build script, and ran into the following problems within the docker container.

  1. I had to export LD_LIBRARY_PATH=/usr/local/lib:$LD_LIBRARY_PATH
  2. running ign-gazebo results in the following error:
QStandardPaths: XDG_RUNTIME_DIR not set, defaulting to '/tmp/runtime-root'
qt.qpa.screen: QXcbConnection: Could not connect to display 
Could not connect to any X display.

pullrequest.title: [A-3] Dockerfile and supporting scripts for building ign-gazebo

content.raw:
1. I probably didn’t run into this because I set the install prefix to `/usr` in the build\_ign\_gazebo.sh script \(because it’s in a container and unlikely to pollute\)
2. I haven't been running with GUI, which probably requires something like the `rocker` or Shane’s setup.

I'll change 1 so that it goes in `/usr/local`, which is probably more appropriate, and won’t screw anything up if you run it outside the container and update the \(container's\) bashrc accordingly.
content.html:
1. I probably didn’t run into this because I set the install prefix to /usr in the build_ign_gazebo.sh script (because it’s in a container and unlikely to pollute)
  2. I haven't been running with GUI, which probably requires something like the rocker or Shane’s setup.

I'll change 1 so that it goes in /usr/local, which is probably more appropriate, and won’t screw anything up if you run it outside the container and update the (container's) bashrc accordingly.
